title: Safety Net
text:
"Safety Net" is a song by <a href="Shop%20Assistants">Shop Assistants</a> which was recorded in 1985 and released as a single in 1986.
Recordings.
The song was first recorded for the band's first session for <a href="John%20Peel">John Peel</a>'s <a href="BBC%20Radio%201">BBC Radio 1</a> show on 8 October 1985. It was recorded for release on 24 and 25 October 1985 at Pier House, Edinburgh, and released as a single on guitarist David Keegan and <a href="Stephen%20Pastel">Stephen Pastel</a>'s 53rd & 3rd Records in February 1986, the first release on the label.
Charts and reception.
The single reached number two on the <a href="UK%20Independent%20Chart">UK Independent Chart</a>, spending seventeen weeks in the chart in total. The song was voted to number eight on the 1986 <a href="Festive%20Fifty">Festive Fifty</a>, with only tracks by <a href="The%20Smiths">The Smiths</a>, <a href="Primal%20Scream">Primal Scream</a>, <a href="The%20Fall%20%28band%29">The Fall</a> and "Kiss" by <a href="Age%20of%20Chance">Age of Chance</a> receiving more votes. "Safety Net" was described by David Sheridan of "<a href="Trouser%20Press">Trouser Press</a>" as "nothing short of brilliant". Gillian Watson of "<a href="The%20Scotsman">The Scotsman</a>" called the song an "early classic", which "captures how nervous and exciting it feels to be a young adult in the city at night".
